currentInstance.description: This research attempted to reproduce Figure 4 of Phillips et al. 2006.

publicationData.publicationName: Reproducibility in Ecological Niche Models: the case of Phillips et al (2006)

targetInstance.description: This research introduced the use of MaxEnt for ecological niche modeling

authorAffiliation: Department of Biology, City College of the City University of New York
Division of Vertebrate Zoology (Mammalogy), American Museum of Natural History

publicationData.publicationName: Maximum entropy modeling of species geographic distributions

methodHypotheses.textDescription: MaxEnt is equivalent to regularizing a log-SVM
methodHypotheses.nullHypothesis: SVM outcomes for the same dataset and parameters are indistinguishable from those produced by MaxEnt
methodHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: SVM and MaxEnt outcomes are significantly different

computationalHypotheses.textDescription: MaxEnt results are stable between implementations
computationalHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There are no significant differences in outcomes between MaxEnt implementations
computationalHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: Significant differences exist between outcomes using MaxEnt implementations

computationalHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There are no significant differences between Fig 4 in the paper and the figure produced by other methods
computationalHypotheses.arlternativeHypothesis: There are significant differences between Fig 4 in the paper and the figure produced by other methods

computationalHypotheses.textDescription: The original MaxEnt application is correct
computationalHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There are no significant differences between outcomes computed with a verified numerical method and the original MaxEnt implementation
computationalHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: There are significant differences between outcomes computed with a verified numerical method and the original MaxEnt implementation

scientificHypotheses.textDescription: The area distribution of Bradypus variegatus matches observations.
scientificHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There is no difference between a random spatial distribution and that compared to MaxEnt in terms of extent and prediction power
scientificHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: Random spatial distributions differ with high significance and predictive power from those generated by MaxEnt

scientificHypotheses.textDescription: The area distribution of Microryzomys minutus matches observations.
scientificHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There is no difference between a random spatial distribution and that compared to MaxEnt in terms of extent and prediction power
scientificHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: Random spatial distributions differ with high significance and predictive power from those generated by MaxEnt

methodHypotheses.textDesription: MaXEnt distribution oucomes are different when compared to other methods
methodHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There are no significant differences in the outcome distributions of MaxEnt when compared to other methods
methodHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: Differences between outcome distributions of MaxEnt compared againts other methods are significant

methodHypotheses.textDesription: MaXEnt distribution oucomes are better when compared to other methods
methodHypotheses.nullHypothesis: There are no significant differences in the predictive power of MaxEnt when compared to other methods
methodHypotheses.alternativeHypothesis: MaxEnt has higher predictive power when compared againts other methods

reproductionProblem.problemDescription: Estimate 2D probability distribution from positive observations using properties present in the space

problemEntitites.entityDescription: positive observations with locations in a space

reproductionAttempts.attemptDescription: Reproduce Fig 4 using origina data and scikit-learn

reproductionMethod.methodDescription: MaxEnt through Regularization of an SVM

reproductionData.datasetDescription: Geographical area coverages in the original study
Measured environmental variables for the area coverages in the original study
Positive observation data points in the original study
